slides.title: Introduction to Documents in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Introduction to the role and handling of documents within PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our lesson on documents in PolicyCenter! Today, we'll explore how documents are managed, created, and integrated within the PolicyCenter environment. Whether you're dealing with policy-related documents, correspondences, or other assets, understanding these concepts is key to effectively handling electronic files in Guidewire applications.
slides.ocrText: Documents

slides.title: Understanding Documents
slides.notes: Understanding the basic concept of what constitutes a document in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Before we dive deeper, let's clarify what we mean by documents in PolicyCenter. These are electronic files such as PDFs, Word documents, or emails that aren't part of the contractual policy but still play a crucial role in tracking information, rating policies, and recording communications.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives ¢ Describe how PolicyCenter manages

documents
¢ Articulate the difference between documents

and forms

slides.title: Documents and Forms
slides.notes: Distinction between documents and forms in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: It's important to differentiate between documents and forms. While documents can include anything from emails to photographs, forms are specific contractual components of a policy. Understanding this distinction helps us manage and configure these elements correctly within the system.
slides.ocrText:
Darren (Aa

Insurance
Product Manager

In the new system, we need the ability to create
standard documents like emails and faxes. Is there
an easy way to do this using PolicyCenter?

slides.title: Documents: Definition and Uses
slides.originalNotes:
Documents: definition
Examples of an electronic file include a PDF, a Word document, or an email. Forms are contractual components of a policy and are discussed in a different lesson. Documents are not part of the contractual policy.

Documents can be used to:
Track information or record the assets covered by the policy (i.e., photographs of jewelry, diagrams of a workplace floor plan)
Track information used to rate the policy (i.e., assessments from property inspectors)
Record correspondences with the insured
slides.notes:
Documents: definition
Examples of an electronic file include a PDF, a Word document, or an email. Forms are contractual components of a policy and are discussed in a different lesson. Documents are not part of the contractual policy.

Documents can be used to:
Track information or record the assets covered by the policy (i.e., photographs of jewelry, diagrams of a workplace floor plan)
Track information used to rate the policy (i.e., assessments from property inspectors)
Record correspondences with the insured
slides.narration: Documents help track information about policy coverage, such as photographs or floor plans, and are used for policy rating, like inspection assessments. They're also vital for recording correspondence with insured parties. These documents provide context and support for underwriting and claims processes.

There are two ways to create a document

slides.notes:
Two ways to create documents (I of 2)
There are two ways to create a document
1) Upload an existing electronic file from your computer to the document management system.
slides.narration: There are two primary ways to create documents. The first involves uploading an existing file from your computer to the document management system. This is a straightforward process, often used for documents like scanned images or pre-written reports.

slides.notes:
Two ways to create documents (2 of 2)
2) Create a new document using a PolicyCenter template which creates a local copy on the document production system. It is ultimately uploaded to the document management system.
slides.narration: The second method is generating a new document using a PolicyCenter template. This approach leverages predefined templates to ensure consistency, pulling in relevant data from PolicyCenter to create a draft that can be reviewed and finalized.

slides.title: Document Production Process
slides.originalNotes:
Document production
Document production is the act of creating a draft document by merging a template with a set of business data values. A document template is used to generate commonly needed documents, and includes information drawn from the account, transaction, or policy,  and its related records. The resulting document is a draft; the underwriter can review and modify the document before it becomes final and/or is sent to the relevant party. Document metadata is stored separately from the document.
slides.notes:
Document production
Document production is the act of creating a draft document by merging a template with a set of business data values. A document template is used to generate commonly needed documents, and includes information drawn from the account, transaction, or policy,  and its related records. The resulting document is a draft; the underwriter can review and modify the document before it becomes final and/or is sent to the relevant party. Document metadata is stored separately from the document.
slides.narration: Document production is a key process where templates are merged with business data to produce draft documents. This allows underwriters to review and modify documents before finalization, ensuring accuracy and compliance with policy details.

slides.title: Document Production on External Systems
slides.originalNotes:
Document production on document production system
1. Document templates may be stored in a separate document production system-
When a document is needed, the field values and template name are passed to the document production system. The document production system merges the information and produces a draft which is returned to the user- Document creation does not occur on the PolicyCenter server. Every instance of PolicyCenter has an integration point to a document production application. The application merges templates (may be stored locally) and data. For example , ImageRight is an application used by the insurance industry- 

Information exchange process:
PolicyCenter sends the name of the template and information to be merged-
PolicyCenter receives a draft of the document based on the template with the merged data.

Merged information may include:
The current date
The recipients name and address
The relevant claim number

This integration typically does not require significant effort to plan and configure, however, dismissed- A given instance of PolicyCenter may be integrated with one or more document production applications. Some documents may be created locally on the user's computer while other documents are generated by an application residing elsewhere in the network. This may occur if the carrier has a legacy document production application used for a specific document type. General or newer documents are frequently drafted from the user's computer.
slides.notes:

slides.narration: Document production often occurs on external systems like ImageRight, where templates and data are merged to create drafts. This integration allows PolicyCenter to leverage robust document generation capabilities while maintaining a seamless workflow.

Document production on the PolicyCente server
2. Document templates are stored on the application server that hosts PolicyCenter.
PolicyCenter merges the data and template, creating a draft for the user. This approach may not be typical for documents created in Microsoft Word, but it is typical for open-source formats (that is,  POF).

slides.title: Document Storage Integration
slides.originalNotes:
Document storage integration
Every instance of Policy Center has an integration point to a document storage application which stores master copies ofdocuments. Information exchange includes:
Policy Center can send new or edited document versions to be stored.
Policy Center receives the "master" version of stored documents upon request.
The Image Right document management system was written by Advanced Solutions, Inc., specifically for the insurance industry.

This integration point typically does not require the greatest amount of effort to plan and configure, however, the effort involved is significant. A given instance of Policy Center is typically integrated with a single document storage application.
slides.notes:
Document storage integration
Every instance of Policy Center has an integration point to a document storage application which stores master copies ofdocuments. Information exchange includes:
Policy Center can send new or edited document versions to be stored.
Policy Center receives the "master" version of stored documents upon request.
The Image Right document management system was written by Advanced Solutions, Inc., specifically for the insurance industry.

This integration point typically does not require the greatest amount of effort to plan and configure, however, the effort involved is significant. A given instance of Policy Center is typically integrated with a single document storage application.
slides.narration: PolicyCenter includes robust integration with document storage applications, ensuring that master document versions are properly managed. This integration supports version control and retrieval, crucial for maintaining document integrity and accessibility.

slides.title: Document Management Architecture
slides.originalNotes:
Document management architecture: storage
Each electronic document has a Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions ( MIME) type used by the user's local computer to determine what application to use to view a document (i.e., Adobe Acrobat for PDF files).

For each electronic document, the document management system stores two information sets: 1) the document itself (Word icon); 2) a meta-file which stores information about the document  (i.e., author). Each document has a security type. Sensitive documents are only visible to the author, supervisors, and people with permission to view sensitive documents. Documents in the base application have additional attributes, but no significant functionality is tied to these attributes. Attributes can be configured, and additional attributes may be added.
slides.notes:
Document management architecture: storage
Each electronic document has a Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions ( MIME) type used by the user's local computer to determine what application to use to view a document (i.e., Adobe Acrobat for PDF files).

For each electronic document, the document management system stores two information sets: 1) the document itself (Word icon); 2) a meta-file which stores information about the document  (i.e., author). Each document has a security type. Sensitive documents are only visible to the author, supervisors, and people with permission to view sensitive documents. Documents in the base application have additional attributes, but no significant functionality is tied to these attributes. Attributes can be configured, and additional attributes may be added.
slides.narration: Understanding the architecture of document management is essential. Each document is identified by its MIME type, and metadata such as the author and security levels ensure proper access control. Custom attributes can be added to extend functionality as needed.

slides.title: Document Mailing Processes
slides.originalNotes:
Document mailing
When a new document is created, the carrier may attempt to send a physical copy of the document to the relevant party There may be some electronic communication with relevant parties via email, however, due to legal issues surrounding insurance, most (if not all)  important documents are delivered via postal mail.

There are two ways that the document gets mailed: 
A Policyv Center user prints the document using a printer on the office network and mails it to the recipient via postal services . The user could be a claims adjuster or customer service representative. 
The document management system is responsible for mailing the document. This process involves a flag set on the document (that is, a checkbox labeled "Mail copy to recipient"), and an integration between the document management system and a printing/ mailing system.
slides.notes:
Document mailing
When a new document is created, the carrier may attempt to send a physical copy of the document to the relevant party There may be some electronic communication with relevant parties via email, however, due to legal issues surrounding insurance, most (if not all)  important documents are delivered via postal mail.

There are two ways that the document gets mailed: 
A Policyv Center user prints the document using a printer on the office network and mails it to the recipient via postal services . The user could be a claims adjuster or customer service representative. 
The document management system is responsible for mailing the document. This process involves a flag set on the document (that is, a checkbox labeled "Mail copy to recipient"), and an integration between the document management system and a printing/ mailing system.
slides.narration: When it comes to mailing documents, PolicyCenter offers flexibility. Users can print and mail documents manually, or systems can automate the process with integration flags. This ensures that critical documents reach recipients efficiently, adhering to legal requirements.

slides.title: Demonstration: Document Management
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
DEMO Guidelines
Documents that exist
1.Determine whether the document is related to Account or Policy.
2.Go to the Account or Policy.
3.To create new document, navigate to parent and select Actions New Document-
4.Select the "Link to an existing document" menu item-
5.Navigate to the document by clicking the Browse button.
6.Specify the information about the document.
7.Click Update.

Create documents using a template:
1.Select the template. In the New Document screen, search for and select a template.
2.Generate the document by specifying object values.
3.Modify the document text. 
4.Specify any additional values.
5.Save the documents

Additional Points:
1.Documents Screen (Policy or Account)
2.Document Details in the
3.Document Screen Specifically, Edit Local Copy, Upload and Discard options:

With sufficient permissions, electronic documents can be edited . To edit a document, click the Edit button. PolicyCenter downloads a local copy of the document to your computer and opens it in the appropriate application (i.e., Word). The View and Edit buttons in the Actions cell are replaced with three
new buttons:
Edit Local Copy – Opens the local copy of the document in the appropriate application.
Upload - Replaces the "master" copy of the document in the document management system with your local copy- Use this button after edits have been made to the local copy and the master copy is ready to be updated
Discard - This severs the link between the local and master copies of the document. The Action buttons reverts to View and Edit.

Pay attention to how you can modify and update documents, reflecting the dynamic nature of document handling in the platform.

slides.title: Document Actions Overview
slides.notes: Explore actions available for document handling in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, document actions are crucial for managing the lifecycle of documents. From editing local copies to updating master versions, understanding these actions helps maintain document accuracy and compliance across business processes.

slides.title: Document Permissions and Security
slides.notes: Understanding document security and permissions in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Security is paramount in document management. PolicyCenter provides detailed permission settings to control who can view or edit documents, ensuring sensitive information remains protected while allowing necessary access for business operations.
